intro: Melothria donnell-smithii var. hirtella, commonly known as the hairy melon fruit, is a rare and endemic species native to specific regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the Cucurbitaceae family, which includes cucumbers and gourds, and is characterized by its small, fleshy fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid to semi-arid environments. Its leaves are usually lobed, and the fruit has a distinctive hairy surface, giving it its common name. Due to its limited distribution and unique morphology, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
